docs.lead_paragraph: The changes that the health care bills in Congress envision are years away - not soon enough to help the millions of unemployed people who, on Monday, lost their temporary federal subsidies for health insurance.

headline.main: Millions of Jobless Lose Insurance Aid

docs.abstract: A health care overhaul will not come soon enough to help millions of unemployed people whose federal insurance subsidies are expiring.
docs.snippet: A health care overhaul will not come soon enough to help millions of unemployed people whose federal insurance subsidies are expiring.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senators are beginning to submit a torrent of amendments to the big health care legislation.
docs.abstract: Amendments begin to the Senate health bill.
docs.snippet: Amendments begin to the Senate health bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, who insisted that the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office study the potential effect of health care legislation on premium costs for the majority of Americans who already have health benefits. Mr. Bayh has issued a statement saying that he is reassured by the analysis unveiled by the budget office earlier Monday.

headline.main: Mr. Bayh Reassured by Budget Office Study

docs.abstract: The senator who asked for the budget study sees a "modestly positive impact" on most people's insurance premiums.
docs.snippet: The senator who asked for the budget study sees a "modestly positive impact" on most people's insurance premiums.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Great Health Care Debate of 2009 is under way on the Senate floor, and it took just a scant few minutes for the partisan skirmishing to begin in full force.
docs.abstract: Senate health care debate begins with partisan dueling.
docs.snippet: Senate health care debate begins with partisan dueling.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Congressional Budget Office has released its much-awaited estimate on how the Senate health care bill would affect premiums. It's good news from the point of view of reform advocates: premiums would stay about the same for people with group coverage, while falling significantly for most of those in the small-group or individual markets. Jon Gruber has crunched the numbers, and produces this convenient chart (via Yglesias):
docs.abstract: The CBO has now given the Senate bill a clean bill of, um, health on both its budget impact and its impact on families.
docs.snippet: The CBO has now given the Senate bill a clean bill of, um, health on both its budget impact and its impact on families.

docs.lead_paragraph: The large number of Americans who currently have employer-sponsored medical insurance would not see much change in their premium costs as a result of the health care legislation pending in Congress, according to a widely awaited budget analysis.

headline.main: Premiums for Employee Health Coverage May Change Little, Budget Study Finds

docs.abstract: A much-awaited budget analysis of health care legislation indicates premiums for most people would be little affected.
docs.snippet: A much-awaited budget analysis of health care legislation indicates premiums for most people would be little affected.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: "Insuring the uninsured is a moral imperative," Charles Krauthammer wrote last week. But "the Democrats," he went on, "have chosen the worst possible method - a $1 trillion new entitlement of stupefying arbitrariness and inefficiency." What should we do instead? Krauthammer's answer: Pass "targeted measures that attack the inefficiencies of the current system one by one - tort reform, interstate purchasing and taxing employee benefits."
docs.abstract: The trouble with Charles Krauthammer's health care agenda.
docs.snippet: The trouble with Charles Krauthammer's health care agenda.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.
docs.abstract: An economist asks: Are reproductive rights activists overreacting about the Stupak-Pitts amendment in the health care reform legislation?
docs.snippet: An economist asks: Are reproductive rights activists overreacting about the Stupak-Pitts amendment in the health care reform legislation?

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats in Congress are eager to come up with ways to spur hiring, but at odds over the scope of new measures.

headline.main: Debate on Creating Jobs, Without Raising Deficit
headline.print_headline: Debate on Creating Jobs, Without Raising Deficit

docs.snippet: Democrats in Congress are eager to come up with ways to spur hiring, but at odds over the scope of new measures.

docs.lead_paragraph: The president’s handling of health care reform and Afghanistan will challenge the depth of his support.

headline.sub: Facing Divisions on Health Care and Afghanistan, in Party and Out  ;
headline.print_headline: Vital Tests For Obama On Mandate For Change
headline.seo: Health Care and Afghanistan Are Critical Tests for Obama
headline.main: Vital Tests for Obama on Mandate for Change
